<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 119, 645, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 186]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 279, 208]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 170, 905, 185]]<|/det|>
9702/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 194, 905, 208]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 216, 904, 230]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 506, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 292]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 292, 537, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 226, 351]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 905, 504]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 533, 218, 546]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 570, 596]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 100, 668, 551]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ms}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ms}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\text{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\text{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\text{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{JK}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{Nm}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{Fm}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{mF}^{- 1}\right)\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{Js}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{Wm}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 585, 167, 600]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 612, 325, 840]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\) \(\nu^{2} = \nu^{2} + 2as\) hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\) upthrust \(F = \rho gV\) Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}\nu}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\) electric current \(I = Anvq\) resistors in series \(R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\) resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 341, 88]]<|/det|> Which quantity is a vector? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 228, 116]]<|/det|> **A** pressure <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 255, 141]]<|/det|> **B** temperature <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 210, 167]]<|/det|> **C** weight <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 195, 193]]<|/det|> **D** work <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 222, 94, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 919, 268]]<|/det|> Four students, **A**, **B**, **C** and **D**, have completed an experiment to determine the acceleration of free fall, \(g\). Each student repeated the experiment three times. The determined values of \(g\) are shown in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 625, 299]]<|/det|> Which set of results has a high precision and a low accuracy? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 603, 465]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall/m s-2
experiment 1experiment 2experiment 3
A7.29.48.3
B9.59.810.2
C9.89.89.9
D10.110.210.1

X + YX - Y

Air resistance is negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 765, 677]]<|/det|> What is the displacement from its initial position of the ball after a time of 1.5 s? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 689, 146, 706]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 689, 200, 706]]<|/det|> 11 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 689, 363, 706]]<|/det|> B 19 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 689, 529, 706]]<|/det|> C 37 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 689, 695, 706]]<|/det|> D 41 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 736, 94, 753]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 831, 752]]<|/det|> A surveyor's device emits a pulse of light. The light is reflected from a wall 150 m away. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 919, 797]]<|/det|> What is the total time taken for the pulse to travel from the device to the wall and then back to the device? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 810, 146, 827]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 810, 213, 827]]<|/det|> 0.05 ns <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 810, 383, 827]]<|/det|> B 0.10 ns <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 810, 549, 827]]<|/det|> C 0.50 μs <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 810, 705, 827]]<|/det|> D 1.0 μs

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 73, 919, 107]]<|/det|> Which equation of uniformly accelerated motion can be derived using only the gradient of a velocity–time graph? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 260, 136]]<|/det|> A \(s = \frac{1}{2} (u + v)t\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 260, 164]]<|/det|> B \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 174, 235, 189]]<|/det|> C \(v = u + at\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 267, 215]]<|/det|> D \(v^2 = u^2 + 2as\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 244, 94, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 244, 919, 277]]<|/det|> An object is projected horizontally from a table at time \(t = 0\) . The object falls in a uniform gravitational field. Air resistance is negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 289, 510, 306]]<|/det|> Graphs P, Q, R and S are velocity–time graphs. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 316, 887, 450]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 875, 481]]<|/det|> Which graphs represent the horizontal and vertical components of the velocity of the object? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 408, 622]]<|/det|>
horizontalvertical
AQP
BQS
CRP
DRS

total kinetic energytotal velocity
Ayesyes
Byesno

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
A firework travels vertically upwards in air. Gases are pushed vertically downwards from the firework.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 117, 617, 134]]<|/det|>
Several forces that act on the firework and gases are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[300, 145, 690, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 383, 476, 400]]<|/det|>
Which forces are a Newton's third law pair?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 428, 429]]<|/det|>
A air resistance and force on gases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 354, 454]]<|/det|>
B air resistance and thrust

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 365, 480]]<|/det|>
C force on gases and thrust

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 299, 505]]<|/det|>
D thrust and weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 533, 107, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 533, 801, 550]]<|/det|>
Two blocks K and L slide towards each other along a horizontal frictionless surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 562, 747, 580]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the momentum of the two blocks just before they collide.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 593, 662, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 693, 788, 710]]<|/det|>
During the collision, the blocks are in contact with each other for a time of 0.084 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 723, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
After the collision, the blocks separate and block L moves back along its original path with a momentum of \(0.12 \text{kg} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 769, 890, 786]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the average force exerted on block L by block K during the collision?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 797, 148, 815]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 797, 200, 815]]<|/det|>
3.1N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 797, 365, 815]]<|/det|>
B 4.0N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 797, 532, 815]]<|/det|>
C 6.9N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 797, 700, 815]]<|/det|>
D 7.1N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|> Leonardo da Vinci proposed a flying machine that would work like a screw to lift the pilot into the air. The 'screw' is rotated by the pilot. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 114, 626, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 275, 640, 292]]<|/det|> The machine and the pilot together have a total mass of \(120\mathrm{kg}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 306, 918, 338]]<|/det|> Which useful output power must the pilot provide to move vertically upwards at a constant speed of \(2.5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 718, 367]]<|/det|> A 48W B 300W C 470W D 2900W <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 394, 107, 411]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 591, 411]]<|/det|> Which row describes a pair of forces that forms a couple? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 424, 457, 568]]<|/det|>
direction of the forcesmagnitude of the forces
Aoppositedifferent
Boppositeequal
Csamedifferent
Dsameequal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 698, 90]]<|/det|>
A uniform cylinder of weight \(25.0 \text{N}\) is suspended from a newton meter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 537, 120]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is fully submerged in water, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 473, 150]]<|/det|>
The reading on the newton meter is 10.0N.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 160, 648, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
The water is replaced by a liquid with a density \(10\%\) greater than the density of water. The cylinder remains fully submerged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 502, 473]]<|/det|>
What is the new reading on the newton meter?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 710, 501]]<|/det|>
A 8.5N B 9.0N C 11.0N D 11.5N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 529, 107, 547]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 529, 920, 561]]<|/det|>
A student balances a \(30 \text{cm}\) ruler on a fulcrum set at the \(15 \text{cm}\) mark. She then places a \(50 \text{g}\) mass on the \(23 \text{cm}\) mark and a \(20 \text{g}\) mass on the \(11 \text{cm}\) mark, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[213, 572, 784, 647]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 705, 677]]<|/det|>
Which mass should she place on the \(7 \text{cm}\) mark to restore the balance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 689, 150, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 689, 195, 707]]<|/det|>
30g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 689, 312, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 689, 372, 707]]<|/det|>
40g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 689, 525, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[540, 689, 700, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>47g</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 689, 700, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[715, 689, 750, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>133g</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 736, 107, 753]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 736, 645, 752]]<|/det|>
A submarine is at a depth of \(130 \text{m}\) below the surface of the sea.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 765, 590, 782]]<|/det|>
The pressure on the submarine due to the sea water is \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 795, 607, 811]]<|/det|>
The submarine sinks to a depth of \(260 \text{m}\) below the surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 825, 522, 841]]<|/det|>
Assume that the density of sea water is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 854, 920, 886]]<|/det|>
What is the difference between the pressures on the submarine due to the sea water at the two depths?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 899, 128, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 899, 170, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>0</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 899, 361, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[380, 899, 408, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>0.5p</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 899, 500, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 899, 678, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>p</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[660, 899, 678, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[700, 899, 728, 916]]<|/det|>
<label>2p</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 520, 90]]<|/det|>
An object is falling in a uniform gravitational field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 868, 120]]<|/det|>
Which two quantities are sufficient to calculate the change in gravitational potential energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 428, 147]]<|/det|>
A mass and acceleration of free fall

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 500, 174]]<|/det|>
B mass and change in vertical displacement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 437, 200]]<|/det|>
C weight and acceleration of free fall

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 510, 225]]<|/det|>
D weight and change in vertical displacement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 585, 271]]<|/det|>
The points X, Y and Z are on a rough, horizontal surface.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 281, 635, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 429, 702, 446]]<|/det|>
A box P is pushed across the surface from X to Y and then from Y to Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
The distance from X to Y is 3.0m. The work done against the frictional force in moving the box from X to Y is 150J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 777, 522]]<|/det|>
The work done against the frictional force in moving the box from Y to Z is 200J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 535, 590, 552]]<|/det|>
An identical box Q is pushed in a straight line from X to Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 806, 581]]<|/det|>
The magnitude of the frictional force between the boxes and the surface is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 752, 611]]<|/det|>
How much extra work is done against the frictional force in moving P than Q?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 623, 200, 640]]<|/det|>
A 100J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 623, 368, 640]]<|/det|>
B 250J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 623, 534, 640]]<|/det|>
C 350J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 623, 700, 640]]<|/det|>
D 600J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 670, 107, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 670, 603, 687]]<|/det|>
The momentum of a car of mass \(m\) increases from \(p_{1}\) to \(p_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 551, 716]]<|/det|>
What is the increase in the kinetic energy of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 136, 750]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 724, 717, 757]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{(p_2^2 - p_1^2)}{2m}\qquad \mathsf{B}\qquad \frac{(p_2 - p_1)^2}{2m}\qquad \mathsf{C}\qquad \frac{p_2 - p_1}{2m}\qquad \mathsf{D}\qquad \frac{p_1 - p_2}{2m}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 551, 90]]<|/det|>
A parachutist is falling at constant (terminal) velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 383, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 136, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 131, 737, 148]]<|/det|>
Gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 136, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 158, 806, 175]]<|/det|>
Gravitational potential energy is converted into kinetic energy of the parachutist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 185, 141, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 185, 747, 201]]<|/det|>
Gravitational potential energy is converted into thermal energy of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 211, 816, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 210, 816, 226]]<|/det|>
Gravitational potential energy is converted into thermal energy of the parachutist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 255, 107, 273]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
A student investigates a spring. The variation of the length of the spring with the force applied to the spring is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 297, 695, 437]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 453, 462, 470]]<|/det|>
What is the spring constant of the spring?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 481, 730, 498]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(0.17Nm^{-1}\)  <pre>B \(0.25Nm^{-1}\)  <pre>C \(4.0Nm^{-1}\)  <pre>D \(6.0Nm^{-1}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 527, 107, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 527, 668, 543]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the variation with force of the extension of a wire.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 555, 734, 711]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 727, 900, 744]]<|/det|>
The force is gradually increased to a maximum at Q and then gradually decreased to zero at R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 757, 350, 773]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 139, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 785, 540, 802]]<|/det|>
Along the line PQ, the wire obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 813, 141, 831]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 812, 653, 839]]<|/det|>
Along the line RP, the spring constant is equal to \(\frac{\text{extension}}{\text{force}}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 842, 514, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 842, 512, 858]]<|/det|>
The wire has elastic deformation at point Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 870, 141, 887]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 870, 828, 887]]<|/det|>
The work done in stretching the wire to P is equal to (force \(\times\) extension) at point P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 693, 90]]<|/det|> A uniform metal wire of length \(L\) and diameter \(d\) has spring constant \(k\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 458, 120]]<|/det|> What is the Young modulus of the metal? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 143, 157]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 695, 160]]<|/det|> \[\frac{\pi d^2}{4kL}\qquad \mathsf{B}\qquad \frac{\pi d^2}{kL}\qquad \mathsf{C}\qquad \frac{kL}{\pi d^2}\qquad \mathsf{D}\qquad \frac{4kL}{\pi d^2}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 191, 107, 209]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 570, 208]]<|/det|> An aircraft produces a sound at a frequency of 30.0 Hz. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 221, 432, 238]]<|/det|> The speed of sound in air is \(330 \text{ms}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 252, 919, 283]]<|/det|> The aircraft is directly in front of the stationary observer and travels in a straight line towards or away from the observer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 297, 715, 313]]<|/det|> The observer hears the sound from the aircraft at a frequency of 20.0 Hz. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 327, 504, 344]]<|/det|> What is the speed and direction of the aircraft? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 357, 505, 485]]<|/det|>
speed/ms-1direction
A110away from observer
B110towards observer
C165away from observer
D165towards observer
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 514, 107, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 919, 545]]<|/det|> Which statement about longitudinal and transverse wave motion for a progressive wave is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 556, 744, 573]]<|/det|> A All transverse and longitudinal waves require a medium for propagation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 919, 615]]<|/det|> B All transverse waves travel at the same speed, but longitudinal waves can travel at different speeds. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 919, 656]]<|/det|> C In both transverse waves and longitudinal waves, a particle with zero displacement has a maximum speed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 664, 919, 696]]<|/det|> D In a longitudinal wave there is a net movement of particles in the direction of travel of the wave, but there is no net movement of particles in a transverse wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 725, 107, 743]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 892, 741]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a progressive transverse wave on a stretched string at one instant in time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 755, 416, 771]]<|/det|> One point on the string is labelled X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 784, 559, 801]]<|/det|> Which point on the string is \(270^{\circ}\) out of phase with X? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 812, 672, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 792, 90]]<|/det|>
Which wavelength of electromagnetic radiation in free space could be green light?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 755, 119]]<|/det|>
A \(4.9\times 10^{- 9}\mathrm{m}\) B \(6.6\times 10^{- 9}\mathrm{m}\) C \(5.5\times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{m}\) D \(8.6\times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 147, 107, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 581, 164]]<|/det|>
Which group contains only waves that can be polarised?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 175, 500, 191]]<|/det|>
A infrared waves, radio waves, sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 201, 520, 217]]<|/det|>
B visible light waves, microwaves, radio waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 530, 243]]<|/det|>
C visible light waves, radio waves, sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 530, 269]]<|/det|>
D microwaves, visible light waves, sound waves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 308, 107, 326]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 305, 919, 351]]<|/det|>
One wave has an amplitude of 2A. A second wave has an amplitude of \(\frac{A}{2}\) . The waves are otherwise identical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 579, 381]]<|/det|>
The two waves travel in opposite directions and overlap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 595, 425]]<|/det|>
What is the ratio maximum amplitude of combined wave ? minimum amplitude of combined wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 440, 667, 472]]<|/det|>
A \(\frac{3}{2}\) B \(\frac{5}{3}\) C \(\frac{5}{2}\) D 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 501, 107, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 863, 517]]<|/det|>
Light of wavelength 680 nm is incident normally on a diffraction grating with 450 lines mm\(^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 919, 564]]<|/det|>
What is the angle of diffraction of the second-order maximum in the diffraction pattern that is produced?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 685, 590]]<|/det|>
A \(1.8^{\circ}\) B \(3.5^{\circ}\) C \(18^{\circ}\) D \(38^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 619, 107, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 586, 636]]<|/det|>
A hollow tube is closed at one end and open at the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 858, 666]]<|/det|>
A stationary sound wave of the lowest possible frequency, 820 Hz, is produced in the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 679, 432, 695]]<|/det|>
The speed of sound in air is \(330 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 710, 371, 725]]<|/det|>
What is the length of the tube?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 737, 715, 753]]<|/det|>
A 10 cm B 20 cm C 40 cm D 160 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 783, 107, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 783, 544, 800]]<|/det|>
Which expression gives the definition of resistance?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 812, 465, 828]]<|/det|>
A current divided by potential difference

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 838, 484, 854]]<|/det|>
B current multiplied by potential difference

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 864, 465, 880]]<|/det|>
C potential difference divided by current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 890, 396, 906]]<|/det|>
D resistivity multiplied by length

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 668, 90]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the \(I - V\) characteristic of an electrical component.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 100, 638, 272]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 284, 320, 300]]<|/det|>
What is the component?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 280, 328]]<|/det|>
**A** a filament lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 338, 520, 354]]<|/det|>
**B** a metallic conductor at constant temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 364, 233, 379]]<|/det|>
**C** a resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 343, 405]]<|/det|>
**D** a semiconductor diode

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 434, 107, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 641, 451]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows six identical resistors connected in a circuit.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 462, 650, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 603, 772]]<|/det|>
In which branch of the circuit is the most power dissipated?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 783, 136, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 783, 185, 801]]<|/det|>
PQ

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 783, 352, 801]]<|/det|>
B QR

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 783, 515, 801]]<|/det|>
C RS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 783, 680, 801]]<|/det|>
D SP

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 791, 90]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circuit containing a thermistor, a fixed resistor and a battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 625, 121]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the \(I - V\) characteristics of both components.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 133, 850, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 667, 348]]<|/det|>
The battery has an e.m.f. of 12 V and negligible internal resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 447, 377]]<|/det|>
What is the current in the fixed resistor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 389, 725, 406]]<|/det|>
**A** 0.36 mA **B** 0.40 mA **C** 0.48 mA **D** 0.80 mA

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 434, 107, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 648, 452]]<|/det|>
Two resistors of resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\) are connected in parallel.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 462, 641, 543]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 546, 577]]<|/det|>
What is the combined resistance between X and Y?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 687, 622]]<|/det|>
**A** \(R_{1} + R_{2}\) **B** \(\frac{R_{1}R_{2}}{R_{1} + R_{2}}\) **C** \(\frac{R_{1} + R_{2}}{R_{1}R_{2}}\) **D** \(\frac{R_{1}}{R_{2}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 73, 919, 120]]<|/det|>
A cell is connected in series with an ammeter and a variable resistor. A voltmeter is used to measure the p.d. across the variable resistor. The resistance of the variable resistor is varied, and the p.d. and the current are recorded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 786, 149]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the variation with current of the p.d. across the variable resistor.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 161, 750, 517]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 532, 463, 548]]<|/det|>
What is the internal resistance of the cell?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 695, 577]]<|/det|>
A \(0.050\Omega\) B \(1.6\Omega\) C \(20\Omega\) D \(23\Omega\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 606, 107, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 606, 504, 623]]<|/det|>
Which list contains only fundamental particles?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 635, 504, 650]]<|/det|>
A antineutrinos, baryons, neutrons, electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 464, 676]]<|/det|>
B mesons, electrons, neutrinos, protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 445, 702]]<|/det|>
C positrons, quarks, hadrons, protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 713, 452, 728]]<|/det|>
D quarks, positrons, neutrinos, leptons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why alpha-particles have discrete energies, but beta-particles have a continuous range of energies?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 136, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 117, 918, 149]]<|/det|>
Beta-particles have a much smaller mass than alpha-particles which means beta-particles can be emitted with a larger range of velocities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 136, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 158, 918, 189]]<|/det|>
Only alpha-particles experience repulsion from the nucleus which is dependent on the number of protons in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 199, 136, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 199, 918, 230]]<|/det|>
Only beta-particles are emitted with another lepton and some energy is transferred to the other lepton.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 136, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 240, 918, 271]]<|/det|>
Only the energy of alpha-particles is discrete because the composition of alpha-particles is always the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 300, 107, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 547, 316]]<|/det|>
A hadron consists of antiquarks that are all identical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 875, 346]]<|/det|>
What is a possible value, in terms of the elementary charge \(e\) , for the charge on the hadron?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 136, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 178, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>0e</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 358, 354, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 358, 520, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 358, 688, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[660, 358, 688, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>+3e</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 388, 136, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 388, 176, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>0e</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 388, 354, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 388, 520, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 388, 688, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[660, 388, 688, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>+3e</label>
